texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: I had a great time on the  Fedora Podcast  yesterday to talk about Fedora cloud! We talked about all kinds of Fedora-related topics, but a couple of questions came up around how to contribute, especially when there's not a lot of structure in place for a particular type of contributions. Here's the full video if you're interested:
texts.text: I had a great time on the  Fedora Podcast  yesterday to talk about Fedora cloud! We talked about all kinds of Fedora-related topics, but a couple of questions came up around how to contribute, especially when there's not a lot of structure in place for a particular type of contributions. Here's the full video if you're interested:

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: {{< youtube id="aA-pBYxUPgU" autoplay="true" >}}
texts.text: {{< youtube id="aA-pBYxUPgU" autoplay="true" >}}

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: That made me think about a post that deserves to be written: How do you get started with open source contributions in a new project?  🤔
texts.text: That made me think about a post that deserves to be written: How do you get started with open source contributions in a new project?  🤔

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: My answer is pretty simple: Just do it.  🚀
texts.text: My answer is pretty simple: Just do it.  🚀

texts.label: title
texts.orig: Just do what?
texts.text: Just do what?

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: In the late 1980's, one of Nike's ad agencies  came up with the phrase  as a way to push through uncertainty. I was pretty young when this campaign started, but the general idea was this:
texts.text: In the late 1980's, one of Nike's ad agencies  came up with the phrase  as a way to push through uncertainty. I was pretty young when this campaign started, but the general idea was this:

texts.label: list_item
texts.orig: Anyone can achieve what they want
texts.text: Anyone can achieve what they want

texts.label: list_item
texts.orig: Stop worrying about whether you can actually do something
texts.text: Stop worrying about whether you can actually do something

texts.label: list_item
texts.orig: Try something new
texts.text: Try something new

texts.label: list_item
texts.orig: Just do it
texts.text: Just do it

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: Simple, right?
texts.text: Simple, right?

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: This works for open source contributions, too. I often have conversations with people inside and outside of work where they identify a problem or an improvement in an open source project. My customary response is  "Let's go upstream and make this better!"
texts.text: This works for open source contributions, too. I often have conversations with people inside and outside of work where they identify a problem or an improvement in an open source project. My customary response is  "Let's go upstream and make this better!"

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: However, what I hear back most often is  "I don't know how." This is where the whole  just do it  part comes in.
texts.text: However, what I hear back most often is  "I don't know how." This is where the whole  just do it  part comes in.

texts.label: title
texts.orig: I found a bug
texts.text: I found a bug

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: Nearly every open source project wants to know about bugs that users experience. Start by finding out the best way to communicate with the people working on a particular project.
texts.text: Nearly every open source project wants to know about bugs that users experience. Start by finding out the best way to communicate with the people working on a particular project.

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: For projects on GitHub or GitLab, you can open up an issue and describe your problem. Some repositories have a template generated for bugs that ask you several important questions, so be sure to follow those templates. If there isn't a template, I usually follow this format:
texts.text: For projects on GitHub or GitLab, you can open up an issue and describe your problem. Some repositories have a template generated for bugs that ask you several important questions, so be sure to follow those templates. If there isn't a template, I usually follow this format:

texts.label: list_item
texts.orig: What happened that was unexpected?
texts.text: What happened that was unexpected?

texts.label: list_item
texts.orig: What were you doing right before that unexpected event happened?
texts.text: What were you doing right before that unexpected event happened?

texts.label: list_item
texts.orig: What did you expect to happen instead?
texts.text: What did you expect to happen instead?

texts.label: list_item
texts.orig: What else is nearby in the environment that might have an impact?
texts.text: What else is nearby in the environment that might have an impact?

texts.label: list_item
texts.orig: For example, the versions of Python might be important for Python-based projects.
texts.text: For example, the versions of Python might be important for Python-based projects.

texts.label: list_item
texts.orig: What log files or other diagnostic materials exist?
texts.text: What log files or other diagnostic materials exist?

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: What's the goal? We want to give maintainers enough information for a quick diagnosis in the best case. If it's not obvious, then they need enough information to try to reproduce it on their own machine for debugging.
texts.text: What's the goal? We want to give maintainers enough information for a quick diagnosis in the best case. If it's not obvious, then they need enough information to try to reproduce it on their own machine for debugging.

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: Maintainers might come back with additional questions about your environment or the events just before the bug occurred. Be sure to respond in a timely way while the information is top of mind for them.
texts.text: Maintainers might come back with additional questions about your environment or the events just before the bug occurred. Be sure to respond in a timely way while the information is top of mind for them.

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: Always remember that these maintainers are real people who are likely not being paid for their work. Assume the best of intentions (unless proven otherwise) and stay focused on the solution. There might always be the chance that the maintainers are not interested in your use case and might not be interested in solving it.
texts.text: Always remember that these maintainers are real people who are likely not being paid for their work. Assume the best of intentions (unless proven otherwise) and stay focused on the solution. There might always be the chance that the maintainers are not interested in your use case and might not be interested in solving it.

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: That leads me to the next step.
texts.text: That leads me to the next step.

texts.label: title
texts.orig: I found a bug and I want to fix it
texts.text: I found a bug and I want to fix it

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: Start by opening an issue or a bug report first (see the previous section).
texts.text: Start by opening an issue or a bug report first (see the previous section).

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: This ensures that maintainers get a full picture of the problem you're trying to solve. Also, I've had maintainers immediately reply and tell me that it's a known issue already being solved in another issue. That could save you some work.
texts.text: This ensures that maintainers get a full picture of the problem you're trying to solve. Also, I've had maintainers immediately reply and tell me that it's a known issue already being solved in another issue. That could save you some work.

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: If you have a patch that fixes the issue, go through the following steps before submitting the fix upstream:
texts.text: If you have a patch that fixes the issue, go through the following steps before submitting the fix upstream:

texts.label: list_item
texts.orig: Ensure your fix references the issue or bug report that you opened
texts.text: Ensure your fix references the issue or bug report that you opened

texts.label: list_item
texts.orig: Use a very clear first line in your commit message, such as
texts.text: Use a very clear first line in your commit message, such as

texts.label: list_item
texts.orig: Include a very brief explanation of the bug you're fixing in the commit message
texts.text: Include a very brief explanation of the bug you're fixing in the commit message

texts.label: list_item
texts.orig: [<RawText children='Extra credit:'>]
texts.text: [<RawText children='Extra credit:'>]

texts.label: list_item
texts.orig: [<RawText children='Extra credit:'>]
texts.text: [<RawText children='Extra credit:'>]

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: These extra credit items often make it easier to review your patch. Maintainers love extra test coverage, too.
texts.text: These extra credit items often make it easier to review your patch. Maintainers love extra test coverage, too.

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: Submit your change in a pull request or merge request and watch for updates. Be patient with replies from the maintainers, but be timely in your replies. Remember that your use case might be an edge case for the upstream project and you might need to explain your fix (or the original bug) in more detail.
texts.text: Submit your change in a pull request or merge request and watch for updates. Be patient with replies from the maintainers, but be timely in your replies. Remember that your use case might be an edge case for the upstream project and you might need to explain your fix (or the original bug) in more detail.

texts.label: title
texts.orig: I want to improve something
texts.text: I want to improve something

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: Improving an open source project could involve several things, such as:
texts.text: Improving an open source project could involve several things, such as:

texts.label: list_item
texts.orig: Enhancing by adding a new feature
texts.text: Enhancing by adding a new feature

texts.label: list_item
texts.orig: Optimizing an existing feature
texts.text: Optimizing an existing feature

texts.label: list_item
texts.orig: Creating documentation
texts.text: Creating documentation

texts.label: list_item
texts.orig: Building integrations
texts.text: Building integrations

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: I strongly recommend opening an issue first with the project maintainers to explain your enhancement. These  Requests for Enhancements , or RFEs, should include several things:
texts.text: I strongly recommend opening an issue first with the project maintainers to explain your enhancement. These  Requests for Enhancements , or RFEs, should include several things:

texts.label: list_item
texts.orig: Your use case that made you think of the enhancement in the first place
texts.text: Your use case that made you think of the enhancement in the first place

texts.label: list_item
texts.orig: What you plan to add, substract, or change
texts.text: What you plan to add, substract, or change

texts.label: list_item
texts.orig: How the changes might affect different users, especially as they upgrade from older versions
texts.text: How the changes might affect different users, especially as they upgrade from older versions

texts.label: list_item
texts.orig: How the changes might affect testing or release processes
texts.text: How the changes might affect testing or release processes

texts.label: list_item
texts.orig: Any changes in dependencies required
texts.text: Any changes in dependencies required

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: Before going down the road of enhancements, always bring up these ideas with the maintainers first. You want to ensure that your ideal changes are aligned with the future goals of the project. In addition, maintainers will want to better understand your use case.
texts.text: Before going down the road of enhancements, always bring up these ideas with the maintainers first. You want to ensure that your ideal changes are aligned with the future goals of the project. In addition, maintainers will want to better understand your use case.

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: Remember that an enhancement almost always requires additional work from maintainers. Every new use case means more work to ensure the project still functions. That's why it's critical to share your use case and have a good plan for testing and documentation.
texts.text: Remember that an enhancement almost always requires additional work from maintainers. Every new use case means more work to ensure the project still functions. That's why it's critical to share your use case and have a good plan for testing and documentation.

texts.label: title
texts.orig: Getting involved
texts.text: Getting involved

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: Whenever I find an open source project that I'd like to get involved with, I start looking around for several things:
texts.text: Whenever I find an open source project that I'd like to get involved with, I start looking around for several things:

texts.label: list_item
texts.orig: [<RawText children='What do they use for informal asynchronous chat?'>]
texts.text: [<RawText children='What do they use for informal asynchronous chat?'>]

texts.label: list_item
texts.orig: [<RawText children='Where do they have detailed discussions?'>]
texts.text: [<RawText children='Where do they have detailed discussions?'>]

texts.label: list_item
texts.orig: [<RawText children='What requirements exist for contributors?'>]
texts.text: [<RawText children='What requirements exist for contributors?'>]

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: From there, I take the  just do it  mentality and go for it. The worst thing you'll be told is  "No" . If that happens, take a step back, see if there's another way to approach it, and try again.
texts.text: From there, I take the  just do it  mentality and go for it. The worst thing you'll be told is  "No" . If that happens, take a step back, see if there's another way to approach it, and try again.

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: Remember one thing most of all:  avoid taking anything personally. All of us have our bad days and some people have personalities that might be totally incompatible with yours (and most people in general). 🤭
texts.text: Remember one thing most of all:  avoid taking anything personally. All of us have our bad days and some people have personalities that might be totally incompatible with yours (and most people in general). 🤭
